cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ancient Egyptian tombs contain the deceased who are buried within them.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: at the time of burial and afterward

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ancient Egyptian tombs also contain grave goods placed with the deceased.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: inside the tombs next to the deceased
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: items to accompany them in the afterlife

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The burial chamber houses the deceased individual along with texts and amulets.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
remarks: Relation inferred from funerary context; not literally spelled out in the excerpt.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject physically contains or encloses the object within its spatial boundaries (object is located inside the subject).
args.justification: All three relations describe a physical spatial containment: tombs or a burial chamber enclosing the deceased or grave goods. Despite wording differences like 'contains' vs 'houses', the underlying predicate is the same physical containment relation.
These relations all belong to the same conceptual family where one physical structure serves as the enclosing container for persons or objects (deceased, grave goods) located inside it.
The primary semantic dimension is spatial: all relations describe where the object is located relative to the subject (inside/enclosed by it), not composition, causality, or identity.
